metadata.titleEn: Dataset of Heihe integrated observatory network (eddy covariance system of Huazhaizi station, 2023)
metadata.description:
This dataset contains the flux measurements from the Huazhaizi station eddy covariance system (EC) in the midstream reaches of the Heihe integrated observatory network from January 1 to December 31 in 2023. The site (100.3201° E, 38.7659° N) was located in the Zhangye City in Gansu Province. The elevation is 1731 m. The EC was installed at a height of 4.5 m, and the sampling rate was 10 Hz. The sonic anemometer faced north, and the separation distance between the sonic anemometer and the CO2/H2O gas analyzer (CSAT3&Li7500A) was 0.15 m.
The raw data acquired at 10 Hz were processed using the Eddypro post-processing software, including the spike detection, lag correction of H2O/CO2 relative to the vertical wind component, sonic virtual temperature correction, coordinate rotation (2-D rotation), corrections for density fluctuation (Webb-Pearman-Leuning correction), and frequency response correction. The EC data were subsequently averaged over 30 min periods. The observation data quality was divided into three classes according to the quality assessment method of stationarity (Δst) and the integral turbulent characteristics test (ITC): class 1-3 (high quality), class 4-6 (good), class 7-8 (poor, better than gap filling data), class9 (rejected). In addition to the above processing steps, the half-hourly flux data were screened in a four-step procedure: (1) data from periods of sensor malfunction were rejected; (2) data collected before or after 1 h of precipitation were rejected; (3) incomplete 30 min data were rejected when the missing data constituted more than 10% of the 30 min raw record. There were 48 records per day, and the missing data were replaced with -6999. Suspicious data were marked in red. 
The released data contained the following variables: data/time, wind direction (Wdir, °), wind speed (Wnd, m/s), the standard deviation of the lateral wind (Std_Uy, m/s), virtual temperature (Tv, ℃), H2O mass density (H2O, g/m3), CO2 mass density (CO2, mg/m3), friction velocity (ustar, m/s), stability (z/L), sensible heat flux (Hs, W/m2), latent heat flux (LE, W/m2), carbon dioxide flux (Fc, mg/ (m2s)), quality assessment of the sensible heat flux (QA_Hs), quality assessment of the latent heat flux (QA_LE), and quality assessment of the carbon flux (QA_Fc). In this dataset, the time of 0:30 corresponds to the average data for the period between 0:00 and 0:30; the data were stored in *.xls format. Detailed information can be found in the suggested references.
For more information, please refer to Liu et al. (2018) and Liu et al. (2023).

background: Arid and semiarid regions represent approximately 30 % of the global terrestrial surface area (Dregne, 1991; Scanlon et al., 2006), and dryland expansion occurs under climate change, especially in developing countries (Huang et al., 2016). An oasis is a unique ecological landscape in arid and semi-arid areas that is not only the core of regions’ ecological environment but also the foundation of their economic development, especially in western China, which has been an important part of the “Silk Road” since ancient times. Oases comprising less than 10 % of the total area of arid regions support more than 90 % of the population in these regions of China (Chu et al., 2005; Li et al., 2016; Zhou et al., 2022). The oasis–desert system plays a crucial role in maintaining a stable ecological environment and agricultural productivity (Zhang and Zhao, 2015). Extensive studies have investigated energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas based on field and remote-sensing observations (Taha et al., 1991; Potchter et al., 2008; Xue et al., 2019; Wang et al., 2019; Zhou et al., 2022) and numerical simulations (Chu et al., 2005; Meng et al., 2009; Georgescu et al., 2011; Liu et al., 2020). In addition, oasis–desert areas located in semiarid regions have been found to be carbon sinks by previous researchers (Tagesson et al., 2016; Wang et al., 2019); thus, they can significantly affect the carbon balance of arid regions and play an increasingly important role within the global carbon cycle.
research objective: Therefore, it is critical to maintain the balance between oasis and desert systems in order to achieve the goal of sustainable oasis development. Understanding the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems is important to achieve the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality in the oasis–desert area and support the ecological security and sustainable development of the oasis. A quantitative understanding of the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas is crucial to recognize the oasis–desert interactions and is significant to protect the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases; moreover, long-term observations are indispensable.
challenges: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas are facing the crisis of ecological environment degradation, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, the degradation of natural vegetation, the intensification of land desertification, and the frequent occurrence of dust storms, especially in many inland river basins westward along the Silk Road, such as the Tarim River basin (Zhao et al., 2013), the Aral Sea basin (Stanev et al., 2004; Crétaux et al., 2009), and the Lake Urmia basin (Stone, 2015).
methods: In this study, we present a suite of observational datasets from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems that consist of long-term energy, water vapor, carbon and methane fluxes as well as auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters from 2012 to 2021. Half-hourly turbulent flux data were acquired by an eddy covariance system and scintillometer. The hydrometeorological data (including radiation, soil heat flux, and soil temperature profiles; gradients of air temperature and humidity and of wind speed and direction; and air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles) were observed from automatic weather stations with a 10 min average period as well as the groundwater table data. Moreover, vegetation and soil parameters were also supplemented in the datasets. The data processing and quality control procedure can be divided into data collection, data processing, and data archiving and sharing.
dataset: The study area comprises the middle and lower reaches of the HRB, located in the arid regions of western China, that receive water from the typical cryosphere of the upper reaches. A total of 11 land surface flux and meteorological stations have been established in these regions since 2012 – 2 superstations and 9 ordinary stations. The dataset of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange observations in oasis–desert areas reported in this study (including energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes; hydrometeorological data; and vegetation and soil parameters) is freely available from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center.

Example.Answer: An example of a data collection method used in arid regions is the eddy covariance system, which collects energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange data. This method involves the use of an eddy covariance system to capture half-hourly turbulent flux data, supplemented by hydrometeorological, vegetation, and soil data from automatic weather stations.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced in maintaining long-term observational datasets in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Example.Answer: A challenge faced in maintaining long-term observational datasets in oasis–desert ecosystems includes the crisis of ecological environment degradation, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, degradation of natural vegetation, intensification of land desertification, and frequent dust storms, particularly in inland river basins like the Tarim River basin.

Definition.Question: What is the eddy covariance method used for in the context of data collection in arid and semiarid regions?
Definition.Answer: The eddy covariance method is used to measure turbulent fluxes of energy, water vapor, and carbon dioxide in oasis–desert ecosystems, providing insights into the interactions between these elements.

Definition.Question: What does 'quality control procedure' involve in the context of data collection for oasis–desert ecosystems?
Definition.Answer: Quality control procedures in this context involve data collection, processing, and archiving, ensuring the accuracy and reliability of energy, water vapor, and carbon flux data, as well as auxiliary hydrometeorological data.

Interpretation.Question: What methodologies can be inferred to handle the challenges of ecological environment degradation in arid inland river basins when collecting data?
Interpretation.Answer: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas face ecological degradation challenges such as drying rivers, land desertification, and dust storms. To handle these challenges, researchers use long-term observational datasets from oasis–desert systems that include energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes. These datasets involve hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters, collected using systems like eddy covariance and automatic weather stations. Data processing involves quality control and archiving to ensure data reliability.

Interpretation.Question: How can the data collection methods for oasis–desert ecosystems be interpreted to support sustainable development and ecological security?
Interpretation.Answer: Data collection methods in oasis–desert ecosystems involve understanding energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange using eddy covariance systems and scintillometers. These methods are crucial for maintaining balance in oasis–desert systems and achieving goals like carbon neutrality. Observations provide quantitative insights into interactions within these ecosystems, supporting sustainable development and ecological security through informed decision-making.

Interpretation.Question: What underlying data collection techniques are suggested for improving the quality and reliability of datasets in oasis–desert systems?
Interpretation.Answer: Improving quality and reliability in datasets for oasis–desert systems involves rigorous data processing techniques such as wild value removal, time delay correction, coordinate rotation, and density correction. Quality evaluation of flux values includes tests for atmospheric stability and turbulence similarity. Data collection also involves removing erroneous data and data with high missing rates, ensuring only high-quality data is archived and shared.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is it essential to maintain the balance between oasis and desert systems for sustainable oasis development?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Maintaining the balance between oasis and desert systems is crucial for sustainable oasis development because oases are the core of ecological and economic environments in arid and semi-arid regions, supporting a significant portion of the population. This balance is vital for achieving carbon peaking and neutrality, ecological security, and socio-economic development. The oasis–desert interactions significantly impact the carbon balance and ecological stability, influencing the global carbon cycle and local agriculture productivity.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the degradation of ecological environments in inland river basins within arid and semi-arid regions?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The degradation of ecological environments in inland river basins within arid and semi-arid regions is caused by factors such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, degradation of natural vegetation, intensified land desertification, and frequent dust storms. These challenges are particularly prevalent in many inland river basins along the Silk Road, exacerbated by climate change and anthropogenic impacts. Such environmental degradation threatens the ecological balance and sustainability of oasis–desert systems.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the main objectives for collecting energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange data in oasis-desert ecosystems using eddy covariance systems?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The main objectives include achieving carbon peaking and carbon neutrality in oasis-desert areas, supporting ecological security and sustainable development of the oasis, and protecting the ecological stability and socioeconomic development through a quantitative understanding of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in these ecosystems.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it essential to understand the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis-desert ecosystems?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Understanding these characteristics is crucial to maintain the balance between oasis and desert systems, which is vital for sustainable oasis development and to support the ecological security and sustainable development of the oasis, especially in the context of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality goals.

Goal Orientation.Question: What motivates the establishment of long-term observational datasets in oasis-desert systems?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The motivation lies in the need for long-term observations to quantitatively understand oasis-desert interactions, contribute to ecological stability, and support the socioeconomic development of oases, which are critical to achieving sustainable development goals and addressing environmental challenges in arid and semi-arid regions.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can datasets from oasis–desert systems be effectively collected and integrated to understand long-term energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange dynamics?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Datasets can be effectively collected and integrated by establishing multiple land surface flux and meteorological stations, as seen in the middle and lower reaches of the HRB in arid western China. These stations should monitor a range of parameters including energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes, as well as hydrometeorological, vegetation, and soil parameters. Data collection should involve both artificial and natural systems with long-term observations, and use tools like eddy covariance systems and scintillometers.

Enablement.Question: What data processing techniques enable the transformation of raw observations into usable datasets in the field of oasis–desert ecosystems?
Enablement.Answer: The data processing techniques include the use of Eddypro software for processing raw 10Hz data into 30-minute interval datasets, which involves steps such as outlier removal, time delay correction, coordinate rotation, frequency response correction, ultrasonic virtual temperature correction, and density corrections. Quality evaluation of flux values is also a part of the process.

Enablement.Question: How do observational datasets from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems enable the understanding of energy and carbon exchanges?
Enablement.Answer: Observational datasets from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems, which include long-term data on energy, water vapor, carbon, and methane fluxes along with auxiliary data on hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters, provide a quantitative understanding of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange, crucial for recognizing oasis–desert interactions and supporting ecological stability and socioeconomic development.

Expectation.Question: Why might the quality control procedures for data collected in oasis-desert ecosystems need to be particularly rigorous?
Expectation.Answer: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas are facing the crisis of ecological environment degradation, which includes the drying up of rivers and lakes, the degradation of natural vegetation, and the intensification of land desertification. These challenges necessitate rigorous quality control procedures to ensure accurate data collection and analysis in oasis-desert ecosystems.

Expectation.Question: What factors could lead to difficulties in maintaining long-term observational datasets in oasis-desert areas?
Expectation.Answer: Oasis-desert areas are often located in regions facing ecological degradation, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, land desertification, and frequent dust storms. These environmental challenges could contribute to difficulties in maintaining long-term observational datasets.

Expectation.Question: How might the unique characteristics of oasis-desert systems influence the choice of data collection methods?
Expectation.Answer: The oasis-desert system plays a crucial role in maintaining ecological stability and agricultural productivity. Understanding the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in these areas is essential for achieving sustainable development goals, which might influence the choice of data collection methods that can accurately capture these exchanges.

Judgmental.Question: How effective are the current data collection methods in capturing the complexities of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Judgmental.Answer: The current data collection methods, utilizing eddy covariance systems and scintillometers for half-hourly turbulent flux data, appear to be effective in capturing the complexities of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange. These methods are complemented by auxiliary hydrometeorological data and vegetation and soil parameters, which provide a comprehensive view of the ecosystem dynamics.

Judgmental.Question: What challenges might researchers face when ensuring the quality and consistency of datasets collected in arid and semiarid regions?
Judgmental.Answer: Researchers might face challenges related to ecological environment degradation such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, land desertification, and dust storms. These factors can impact the stability and consistency of long-term observations, necessitating rigorous quality control procedures and data processing techniques to ensure reliability.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure about the challenges faced in collecting long-term observational data in the oasis-desert ecosystems.
Assertion.Answer: Challenges in collecting long-term observational data include ecological environment degradation, such as drying up of rivers and lakes, degradation of natural vegetation, and intensification of land desertification. These challenges are especially prevalent in inland river basins along the Silk Road, which can affect data continuity and quality.

Request/Directive.Question: Please develop a comprehensive overview of the data collection methods used for observing energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems, including the technologies and instruments involved.
Request/Directive.Answer: The data collection methods for observing energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems involve using an eddy covariance system and scintillometer for acquiring half-hourly turbulent flux data. Additionally, automatic weather stations are used to collect hydrometeorological data, such as radiation, soil heat flux, soil temperature profiles, gradients of air temperature and humidity, wind speed and direction, air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles, with a 10-minute average period. Auxiliary data incorporates vegetation and soil parameters, supplemented in the datasets.

Request/Directive.Question: Please identify and analyze the main challenges faced in collecting and processing data related to oasis–desert ecosystem interactions, particularly in inland river basins.
Request/Directive.Answer: The main challenges in collecting and processing data related to oasis–desert ecosystem interactions, especially in inland river basins, include the degradation of the ecological environment, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, degradation of natural vegetation, intensification of land desertification, and frequent dust storms. These challenges are exacerbated in river basins along the Silk Road, such as the Tarim River basin, the Aral Sea basin, and the Lake Urmia basin.

Request/Directive.Question: Please propose potential strategies for expanding or refining datasets on energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in arid regions to enhance understanding of oasis–desert interactions.
Request/Directive.Answer: Potential strategies for expanding or refining datasets on energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in arid regions could include increasing the number of observation stations to cover more diverse and representative areas, implementing long-term monitoring to capture temporal variations, and integrating remote sensing data for broader spatial coverage. Additionally, enhancing data processing and quality control procedures and promoting data sharing through platforms like the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center could significantly enhance the datasets' comprehensiveness and utility.
